awd_titl_txt: RUI: Solution and Thin Film Properties of Dually Stimuli-Responsive Molecular Brush Block Copolymers
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Understanding the fundamental relationships between a polymer's molecular structure and its observed properties allows customizing of the properties for possible applications. A polymer known to dramatically change properties, like the ability to dissolve in water, in response to a small change in an external stimulus, such as temperature and pH, has been selected for detailed investigation. By changing the structure of this polymer to create comb-like of bottlebrush-like molecular architectures from this core polymer and to add chemically distinct segments, it is expected that new polymeric materials will be generated with unique properties both in solution and in thin films. The properties of these polymeric materials can be tailored for potential applications with benefit to society such as polymers for water purification and better targeted and customized drug delivery. These materials will be prepared using a more environmentally benign synthetic approach. New knowledge generated from this work will be shared with a broad scientific audience through publications, presentations, and incorporation into the undergraduate curriculum, and to more general audiences through community and K-12 outreach presentations.  This project will provide full-time immersive research experiences for undergraduate students, particularly for women in materials science and engineering. This will encourage more women to pursue advanced degrees and research careers in science and engineering. 

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The objective of this project is to determine the effect of combining block and branched copolymer architectures with stimuli-responsive properties for the self-assembly of copolymers in solution and in thin films. The stimuli-responsive functionality results in dramatic changes in properties, such as solubility, viscosity, viscoelasticity, interfacial activity, and self-assembly, with a small change in external stimuli. Branched and block copolymer structures affect polymer properties including polymer conformation, chain entanglement behavior, self-assembly, and rheological responses. Stimuli-responsive copolymers with block and branched architectures will be synthesized using the more environmentally benign activator regenerated by electron transfer atom transfer radical polymerization (ARGET ATRP). The pH- and thermo-responsive poly((2-dimethylamino)ethyl methacrylate) (PDMAEMA) has been selected as the primary stimuli-responsive polymer under investigation because it changes solubility and conformation in response to changes in both temperature and pH. The stimuli-responsive functionality of PDMAEMA will be combined with block and branched copolymer architectures in order to generate new materials with expected unique solution and thin film properties. These materials have potential applications in photonics, drug delivery, and viscosity modifiers, including applications that have benefit to society such as polymer membranes for water purification and more tailored drug delivery systems. Undergraduate student research collaborators will fully participate in this immersive high impact experience of undergraduate research. This is expected to increase the retention of undergraduate women in materials science and engineering at the University of Wisconsin-Eau Claire and to encourage more women to pursue advanced degrees and research careers in STEM.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant has supported both the technical success of preparing and testing new stimuli-responsive copolymers, as well as the training and encouraging the persistence of undergraduates in polymer science and pursuing careers in materials science and engineering and related technical fields.

New stimuli-responsive polymers were synthesized and characterized by undergraduate researchers at the University of Wisconsin-Eau Claire. Stimuli-responsive polymers are polymers that dramatically change properties, such as solubility, in response to a small change in an external stimulus like pH or temperature. The stimuli-responsive properties depend on the polymer structure, including both the chemical structure or chemical repeat unit, and the polymer architecture, such as whether there are linear, brush, or star structures. A series of new stimuli-responsive copolymers were prepared to determine the structure-property relationships of these new polymers. Activators ReGenerated by Electron Transfer Atom Transfer Radical Polymerization was used to prepare these new polymers, because this technique provides control over polymer structure while decreasing the environmental impact of the polymerization. This polymerization technique was used by undergraduate researchers to successfully prepare a range of polymer structures for further testing.

The stimuli-responsive properties of each new copolymer were tested to determine the structure-property relationships, and to optimize the properties for applications ranging from architectural coatings to enhanced oil recovery. The stimuli-responsive properties must be finely tuned for each application to achieve the desired effects, and the properties are determined by the polymer structure, including chemical composition and architecture. The newly synthesized stimuli-responsive copolymers were tested to determine the range of stimuli-responsive properties possible for each polymer composition, and to find the optimal composition for potential applications such as architectural coatings. Polymer composition has a direct effect on stimuli-responsive properties, including solubility, viscosity, viscoelasticity, and interfacial activity. Changing polymer block length, number of polymer blocks, and whether the architecture is linear or branched determines how polymer properties change in response to an external trigger. The copolymers investigated in this study are both pH- and temperature-responsive, and changing block length, number of blocks, and branching determines when the properties change as a function of pH and temperature. By understanding the structure-property relationships, the polymer structure can be tuned to achieve the needed stimuli-responsive properties for each application.

Undergraduate researchers at the University of Wisconsin-Eau Claire, a primarily undergraduate institution in the physical sciences, gained hands-on, immersive research experience in polymer science and engineering. This grant directly funded 16 undergraduate students over four years, including seven women, and this funding provided the foundation of the research lab, both through funding for lab supplies, and the recognition of federal funding, enabling a total of 22 undergraduate researchers to participate in this project over four years. All undergraduates learned hands-on technical skills, including polymer synthesis and characterization techniques, and learned to work independently as well as in teams. Each student gained skills in data analysis and experimental design. All student researchers presented their work both to technical audiences and broad multidisciplinary audiences, and had opportunities to present at the local, regional, and national level.

All students were encouraged to persist in their major, with 15 out of 22 participating researchers starting in and staying in materials science and engineering. Of the 15 students who have graduated, all are either in graduate school in materials science or chemistry, or in industry in materials science or other technical fields. Of the seven students who have not yet graduated, all are continuing on the research project and projected to graduate in a timely manner and pursue careers in materials science and engineering.

This grant also provided significant support for the PI to build and sustain an undergraduate research program at UW-Eau Claire. The funding provided the foundation for a polymer synthesis and characterization research lab, including needed lab supplies and reagents, as well as support for ongoing professional development and time/support for the PI to stay engaged and at the cutting edge in the discipline of polymer science and engineering. This grant has provided the support and foundation for the PI to build a sustainable research program within a primarily undergraduate institution, to continue a career as a mentor to undergraduate researchers and impact the education of all engineering majors at UW-Eau Claire.

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2022
Modified by: Elizabeth Glogowski
